1581696052_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc3.body:
> [fractalzoomer@kxoid.bit](#comment_15_1GhYmYygr9AwgLDix4ge5AAQiMa4voJGuC): Devuan

I tried when it forked for the Debian main having hated systemd and much preferred init.d/rc.* coming from a Unix/Solaris/Linux circa 1998), however aside a few niche  distros everyone has engrossed systemd in its entirity (and I have learned to live with it for now), so for me I accept  as is and use  Deb derivatives dependent on how I feel. Purists will say otherwise and in the end its down to preference what you use.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_1878_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): lol "i have my own distro for years now":meaning i can yell and laugh 'at you' anytime i want. Enjoy the "actual state of linuxs because i do, 'was there before', and 'as usual I took the lead' before you. you complain: I ENJOY. lol".

Making your own distro is a complete waste of time, because by the time you have fixed bugs, issues on latest CVEs you're back to square 1 as it  a self fulling prophesy every week. Good luck getting vendor drivers to support your old and ageing hardware as time passes by. All in all an expensive waste of time and money unless you have a thriving community to support  it.

> [h3bhkj5gqz4n3pjm](#comment_1878_1CKTRBy9N4RvE3FgeZJpQqFYtLHc37yo11): lol "i have my own distro for years now":meaning i can yell and laugh 'at you' anytime i want. And I'm sure its upto date, no CVE and totally secure...suuuure, maybe it is, but you waste your  sad little life just so you can say otherwise, congratulations.

1593096815_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKz.body:
Which Distro? Linux  (Windows no idea) 
HW I assume, if its virtual then it depends on what/where /how... you need to be more specific

If this is a physical host and you can mount your host disks with a bootable media and recover everything under /var/lib/docker. tar everything up in /var/lib/docker, scp the tar archive to your new host. On your new host ensure docker is installed, group permission added to the required new user. 

Ensure docker is enabled, however stopped...(backup your existing /var/lib/docker if you're using it or have been, then extract the tar archive into the directory (ensure  you have the same permsissons/ownership as before.  Then startup Docker via systemctl/service or whatever your flavour uses.  This will recover all your images, containers prior to you losing your server, however...

HINT: Don't run any sort of host that isn't back up off site via USB drive (n+1), cloud storage(personally I don't) or a home NAS or some redundant storage solution. I hope this helps

> [robione](#comment_566_1DoVPxFrQCDb3grC8Nsn6aACed9o2oiumX): I use a self hosted setup with Cloudron.io that does all this for you. [...]
thats fine, but when it goes pear shaped you have no idea and if you want to learn more its always a good curve to pick up new skills.

> [merithtk](#comment_57_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKzqW6F8): I like to be in control of my systems myself, no thanls

Same here, I don't like being spoon fed something that I am not in control of or can't get underneath and configure accordingly.

> [merithtk](#comment_56_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKzqW6F8): Ubuntu 18.04 [...]

B> [merithtk](#comment_56_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKzqW6F8): Ubuntu 18.04 [...]

All LTS releases, basically even numbers years now (used to be every multiple of 4) get 10 years of updates. At some point should you still have the host you will need to upgrade, but that a long way off for now. If theres no need to upgrade and you're not bothered then leave it, however should you decide to upgrade ensure you have an offisite BACKUP before you start. The upgrade process/experience from Ubuntu has vastly improved over the years. I never used to do it (when I used it back in 8.04-12.04 days) as it created too many problems it solved.

1594145192_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
Open terminal as root:

    sudo su  #this is bad practice, and inherently wrong... you should be using sudoers and 'sudo su'  will not give you login-specific resource files such as .bash_profile .profile or .login  and will be read by the shell. Neither will it drop yo u into the root ~. this will place you in the current working directory you were in prior to running sudo and enable you delete any files without any recourse whatsoever.

If this is required sudo -i  or sudo -s (gives you the root user shell) would be more optimal...however you should be reading the man pages before running random commands online with no or little knowledge.

Type the following command:

    rm /etc/apt/preferences.d/nosnap.pref  - why are you deleting this file to later rely on it for recovery?

To disable snapd again:

    Open terminal as root:

        sudo su  - we're already logged in as root, says it all really.

These steps are how not to run escalated privilege tasks in any Linux distro.

Lesson to learn, do not run commands you have no idea about because someone blogged out it.

> [styromaniac](#comment_2459_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): Whatever, mate. It's pretty plain to see the instructions are legit and they're found on other reputable sites. [...]

Its not a question of being legit, its a question of being woefully executed, anyway I don't care

> [styromaniac](#comment_2468_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): What are the differences between sudo -i and sudo -s?

-i  run login shell as the target user; a command may also be specified
-s run shell as the target user; a command may also be specified 

personally I use -i  when I require  root as it will pick up variables that you may expect to use, however in most or all instances its better to user sudoers and define the  correct access,  anything else is lazy and in production you can screw yourself over very easily.

> [styromaniac](#comment_2488_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRFtVBhd): And you only have to use either just once per terminal session?

unless you exit out or you ssh config drops your connection  if configured that way. yes.

I would also query why are you deleting 'rm /etc/apt/preferences.d/nosnap.pref' when simply copying it to an alternate location or appending a file extension for later use .bak,  orig or even moving  as it a hidden file unless the   directory is searched by snapd  'mv /etc/apt/preferences.d/nosnap.pref mv .nosnap.pref

Step 3-5  are a waste of time and commands ( you wouldn't want  to do this for a file with 5 or 10lines or more.. far easier to run

cat << EOF > nosnap.pref
Package: snapd
Pin: release a=*
Pin-Priority: -10
EOF

1594835373_14g2gXnsZdEPShFJkGdh5W3eGXmKz.body:
> [randname666](#comment_37_1HpSHmnQ3cp4oP3hRQsqr1f4U5T7ZL29zK): Actually you can do more than that. By running that caddy on a computer with public IP or a VPS, you can access to ZeroNet wherever you are, without using ZeroNet client and to wait for things to sync up. This is insecure though. Also, if you run a Internet website and it's CGI rendered, by fetching Zite first (HTML, JS, CSS, assets, ...) from the caddy then insert it into the website, you can even display ZeroNet contents inside your Internet website.

Something similar using a Zero W and Digitalocean/cloud provider

> [binary1173](#comment_15_17MrYppaLZw5RG3iKFSp4JhL3gMznVgB1G): Something similar using a Zero W and Digitalocean/cloud provider

Might help if I add the link 
https://blog.alexellis.io/raspberry-pi-zero-tunnel-gateway/

1602918342_1BKJiQF8pvdQw99D1XpTG2UJ6eno1.body:
The  first rule of trading has nothing to do with choosing stocks or investing. The market is driven by fear and greed which is a reflection of the price action/market sentiment of a particular asset. You first need to understand  why you lost  so much, in essence the weak point in the equation being you, not your choice of stocks and is risk management is and how to correctly position yourself in and out of trades. I would recommend reading https://www.amazon.co.uk/gp/product/0735201447/ref=ppx_yo_dt_b_search_asin_title?ie=UTF8&psc=1

After understanding this can you only understand how the markets work and how the weak point (you)in the equation needs to behave. Personally I have traded/trade Forex markets due to it being a 24/5 market (Sunday evening to Friday evening) and being way bigger than any  Equity/commodity exchanges....roughty $4Trn per day.

Understand fundamental/technical analysis dependent on your  requirements. Don't overload yourself with Western technical (ignore any news outlets as they  only talk about what has happened and have no idea what is going to happen in the main and you won't learn anything from them)as alot tend to be lagging indicators however with Candlesticks (Steve Nison on youtube brought candlesticks to the Western world in the 80s (the Japanese used them from the 1500/1600s to trade rice so they tell a story..complimented  with Western technicals your winning trades will eventually become more successful than your losing ones) so  I would watch absorb anything he says.

Once you have educated yourself then only then would I open a broker account and paper trade what you have learnt and disciplined yourself to understand and comprehend. Do this for a long time before you even attempt to invest/throw away any money on stocks and continually educate yourself (Steve Nison also does paid training which I am sure you can find on other sites). After that you will start to understand why and how not  to lose money.

Wise words from Warren Buffett 
https://www.investopedia.com/financial-edge/0210/rules-that-warren-buffett-lives-by.aspx

I will say you have to spend money (education) to make money and it doesn't come just because you are trading..otherwise you're gambling like all the other idiots who think they know what they're doing.

> [grouch0](#comment_8_1CrFEcv59gAFWe7w5wbKxCYJg3sDg48tUt): binary makes some good points but neglected to mention some major factors such as the markets are rigged and manipulated. No matter how smart you are unless you're an insider or top man in a major fund you will never have the edge. [...]

Valid points yes indeed, however at some point dependent on your portfolio you need to come to market (most of my portfolio has recovered from the lows seen and posting healthly returns for the year, otherwise all your assets will be illiquid (art, fine wine or whateve)  and hard to liquidate in a rush.I would advocate any portfolio at least 10%  needs precious metals that can't be rebased/revalued by any governments. Crypto obviously has a part to play. However in essence he main criteria is down to Risk and your time frame for the individual...stock picking requires careful attention by anyone as I have proved this year, as I said you have to pay for good advice which  I do. Having an interest in finance helps as you become motivated by the desire and interest it brings.

1606329226_1H9ZCecP2nbVicgXB77yqodz2xp4C.body:
If you have issues with systemd I suggest you look at alternatives like Devuan or here  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Linux_distributions_without_systemd 

Fedora is upstream Alpha Red Hat which relies on the Fedora community for its main source of bug fix/features to feed back into major/minor releases, its not corporate controlled , neither is Arch.

Qubes - non-free, x86-only, unstable, unreliable and cumbersome - no its not, for first time users perhaps.

Linux (the kernel) is mostly bac contributors andked by 2 US corpos now (google and redhat) so I'm not sure we can trust it in the long run. systemd is so complex that there may well be a backdoor that is so obscure even opensourceness keeps it hidden from sight.  - Completely wrong with a multitude on maintainers (1501 including Linus toravalds)  and contributors from all over the world (corporate and Community) there is a diverse collection of people and companies https://www.linuxfoundation.org/wp-content/uploads/2020/08/2020_kernel_history_report_082720.pdf  

It sounds like you don't understand any concept with Linux is (Kernel, gnu utilities and core libraries) Vendors (or anyone for that matter) can take this core building blocks and build their own version/distro which is what is used today under GPL as are most Linux distros if they;re released freely under GPL2/3.

 I suggest you stick to Windows, its easier to comprehend.

1607271673_1Nz5xXKiiTFGd6big5zcBnaGVH3hU.body:
Crypto/Bitcoin is just another asset class and you should diversify your portfolio as you would for any asset class. In the old days it was 60-40 (EQ/bonds) split, however this is no longer true. To most BTC is an alternate to the FIAT (a la no counter party risk)  I deem it high beta gold, so a 5-10% amount of risk is a fair  assumption. 

In short would I invest in one asset class(bitcoin or otherwise), no only a fool would (unless you like high stakes poker and can sleep easy at night)! :D

1610754180_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
Theres more than enough content out there lamenting the reasons not to use telegram, 

https://restoreprivacy.com/secure-encrypted-messaging-apps/telegram/
https://www.vice.com/en/article/jgqqv8/five-reasons-you-should-delete-telegram-from-your-phone

personally I don't rate it very high..signal I am indifferent about. My own personal choice is https://matrix.org/docs/develop E2E, decentralised, open source, federated, bridges https://matrix.org/docs/projects/bridge/  and if so desired you can host your own iteration this is what people should be using and not group thought because someone things its secure. At the end of the day its down to personal preference.

> [freemankind](#comment_61_17AwNLQUY1CRAb1U6jVJhvVUnyEdNvkiue): https://pidgin.im/installhttps://otr.cypherpunks.cahttps://wiki.bitmessage.org

pidgin is purely xmpp based (if you're going to use something like jabber) with otr and bitmessage last version update was 2016, so no on all fronts.

> [freemankind](#comment_70_17AwNLQUY1CRAb1U6jVJhvVUnyEdNvkiue): judas atleast get your facts straight :) [...]

I suggest you check your links that you post Judas  https://wiki.bitmessage.org/

> [freemankind](#comment_71_17AwNLQUY1CRAb1U6jVJhvVUnyEdNvkiue): youre just another troll thats been added to a blacklist

Read my words, something you're unable to comprehend.

> [simonbellamy](#comment_35_1HwJB2bpiPPTctCtysK3198pKjMBY28vAT): Matrix is not decentralized, it is federetad. Your data goes through one and only one server. If it goes down, you're entire system is down. No failover. No backup.-> https://ubinodes.org/portfolio/review-end-to-end-encrypted-chat-server-using-matrix-and-riot/

Freudian slip, however its far more transparent than signal/telegram and I would much prefer to use Matrix over signal/telegram.

> [simonbellamy](#comment_35_1HwJB2bpiPPTctCtysK3198pKjMBY28vAT): Matrix is not decentralized, it is federetad. Your data goes through one and only one server. If it goes down, you're entire system is down. No failover. No backup.-> https://ubinodes.org/portfolio/review-end-to-end-encrypted-chat-server-using-matrix-and-riot/

Any self hosted service would and should be backed up(mine all are, this is no differrent), so the mitigation is dependent on the owner/user and how much effort you want to keep your data/privacy safe.

> [simonbellamy](#comment_39_1HwJB2bpiPPTctCtysK3198pKjMBY28vAT): Yes, but again, you're steering the discussion away from the subject. We're not talking backups here, but decentralization. If their is a single point of failure, then it's not decentralized. Whether the user(s) opt for Matrix (federated) or Signal (US centralized open source) or Telegram (global citizen centralized closed source with multiple servers) is based on the threat model. For Telegram, the biggest threat seems to be state-sponsored criminals (aka governments) so they have servers in many countries, which are as many "jurisdictions" in legal terms. For Signal, it seems they still think US is a state of law (it's a criminal state to the highest order), so for them being open source in the US does the trick. Matrix is another culture, a culture of developers, they are good at programming but utopians. [...]

Everyone is entitled to chose what they want in the realms of security/privacy, the discussion is about these two which personally I would not/do not use. For every argument about easy/comfortable end user ease of use offerings the open source point is there to be made. Bottom line if you want to use these go ahead, but with so many better offerings out there, its short sighted to assume these two 'main stream top 10' will mitigate the risk posed just because everyone else is getting on the band wagon because all it does is move the goal posts into another barrel that Govt can attack or surpress.

> [simonbellamy](#comment_40_1HwJB2bpiPPTctCtysK3198pKjMBY28vAT): For one, it's not encrypted by default

> [simonbellamy](#comment_40_1HwJB2bpiPPTctCtysK3198pKjMBY28vAT): . For one, it's not encrypted by default, you have to create an encrypted chat room 

It seems you're behind the curve  https://matrix.org/blog/2020/05/06/cross-signing-and-end-to-end-encryption-by-default-is-here. People here are likely to be tech orientated so your point is moot in regards moving account, with bridging it offers alot more functionality/choice than signal/telegram ever will.

Theres a video from the Hatedone on YT recently about the whole Signal/Mobilecoin debacle, one to avoid for sure. When Musk tells his plebs to 'Use Signal' you know its had its day, even moreso with the mud slinging with the crypto payments integration. Matrix for me.

A carbon tax will hurt his competitors. Him being in favor of that doesn't surprise me and isn't a concern for me because I expect that from him. But, him stopping the acceptance of bitcoin for Telsa under the idea that it will contribute more people to building server farms and increasing the carbon footprint is flat out wrong and stupid. [...]

If you look at Tesla last quarterly profits reports.. the vast majority was from the sale of carbon credits... vehicles sales were improved, but paltry in comparison. The rhetoric he spouts hides the flaws in his business model and this from a company that will never pay dividends to shareholders (common stock)   “We have never declared or paid cash dividends on our common stock. We currently do not anticipate paying any cash dividends in the foreseeable future. 27 Feb 2021.

Add in the 10 yr treasury yield tripling since August and that debt pile becomes very hard indeed to manage and for any growth (highly leveraged companies).

For the average user this will be far far out of reach for them. In part for their time and more importantly effort to even get something like this or TAILs setup on a usb drive. Convenience over security will always win when you try and force/coerce people into using this sort of setup.

1613425717_16NS3rBdW9zpLmLSQoD8nLTtNVsRF.body:
If you're using an RC (release candidate or nightly version minor/major)  then for all or most versions you will may experience some sort of issues be it new or old hardware dependent with newer kernels. Its safe to say that anything deemed stable is less likley to give you any issues. 

However if you mean stable in the sense of erractic behaviour  I say the only one close to that over the years was Ubuntu wayback when around 12.04. Personally I've used jsut about all of them (or the main ones Centos, Fedora, Mandrake,  suse, opensuse, DSL, Slackware, not Gentoo or Arch BTW)  and all have good and bad points its down to the user experience and sometimes you have to go through them to work out what you like. 

Personally I use Debian derivatives...for user experience Mint is good. I;m not a fan of KDE >3, however mate, gnome an xfce4 are all easy to get to grips if using X.

1634431467_1PxcegJ1mKoMHeS73f9MvXeUWDq8B.body:
> [anonymoose](#comment_51_12Y8rPJTMwJ3tTh5j81JPy6HrMf4KvY6Uq): * * * * * su <replace_with_linux_user> -c "/home/styromaniac/ZeroNet/data/15CEFKBRHFfAP9rmL6hhLmHoXrrgmw4B5o/cache/1/Syncronite.sh"
This will only work if you have the required privileges to run as that user which depends on group membership or perms to run that directory/file, in essence its only really going to work as root... If its something specific that you want to run as a user, then its much easier to define it in /etc/sudoers.d/filename and define the  requirements for that one command there...which gives a better degreee of security..  with something like akin to this  https://kifarunix.com/run-only-specific-commands-with-sudo-in-linux/

> [styromaniac@kxoid.bit](#comment_144_1PxcegJ1mKoMHeS73f9MvXeUWDq8BdnSv3): None of those worked. I'm on Linux Mint 20.2

For debugging bash scripts.. I tend to run $ bash -x  script/name/here.sh as it will give you a verbose output and you can easily see where its failing or failed and you don't have to decipher some cryptic exit code you encounter.

> [styromaniac@kxoid.bit](#comment_142_1PxcegJ1mKoMHeS73f9MvXeUWDq8BdnSv3): Alright, so for some odd reason, v3_trackers only downloads to the proper directory when I manually run Syncronite.sh, not when Syncronite.sh is run by crontab. Same goes for the cat command.

Does /bin/cat not have 755 perms? Owned by root. Sounds like the user is in not in /etc/cron.allow (none are by default, you have to add them and restart cron/crond.
